title: 110_hr2056
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Part D Improvement Act of 2007" and includes a reform of the "donut hole". The Medicare Part D Improvement Act of 2007 includes amendments to counting certain expenditures towards out-of-pocket limits under the Social Security Act. The Medicare Part D Improvement Act of 2007 amended the Social Security Act to include new clauses regarding the treatment of costs incurred and not reimbursed under specific programs. The Medicare Part D Improvement Act of 2007 amended the Social Security Act to include new clauses regarding the treatment of costs incurred and not reimbursed under specific programs, such as those covered under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act, rural health clinics, Federally qualified health centers, AIDS Drug Assistance Program, and pharmaceutical manufacturer patient assistance programs. The Medicare Part D Improvement Act of 2007 amended the Social Security Act to include new clauses regarding the treatment of costs incurred under specific programs. The amendments apply to costs incurred on or after January 1, 2008, for plan years beginning on or after that date. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on how to eliminate the gap in Medicare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on how to eliminate the gap in Medicare Part D prescription drug coverage and finance such elimination, with a report due to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Conforming late enrollment penalty to Medicare Part B penalty structure. Section 1860D-13(b)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to set a penalty of 10 percent of the base beneficiary premium for each continuous period of 12 consecutive uncovered months. Subparagraph (B) is amended to exclude periods of non-enrollment during the first year of the program. Section 1837(h) is amended to presume errors in enrollment or nonenrollment are due to official error. The amendments set penalties for late enrollment in the Social Security Act. The amendments apply to penalties starting in January 2008, with different effective dates for various subsections. The amendments presume errors in enrollment or nonenrollment are due to official error. SEC. 4 allows for more frequent changes in prescription drug plans, aligning with formulary changes. Enrollment changes are permitted in the first 3 months of each year. These amendments take effect on January 1, 2008. SEC. 5 focuses on improvements to low-income subsidies. The removal of asset test requirements under Section 1860D-14(a) of the Social Security Act, effective January 2008, eliminates late enrollment penalties for subsidy eligible individuals. Elimination of late enrollment penalties for subsidy eligible individuals under Section 1860D-13(b)(2) of the Social Security Act by amending certain provisions. The amendments made by this subsection apply to late enrollment penalties starting from January 2008.
